text: Out of curiousity - are there any manual participants who are actually consistently profitable at decent scale? The manual part being computation of value, not just manual execution. I can understand spotting the odd obvious inneficiency or just dropping some passive orders in really wide markets, but this "ladder trading" people continuously talk about where they jump in and out of positions hoping the market goes their way seems no different to a casino. Please enlighten me if I am way off the mark :joy:

text: I guess it totally depends on your approach. Obviously if a market is 1.01/1000 and racingpost says this horse is the favourite to win by miles and you drop a passive back order at 999, then it's probably gonna be value. But people's approach to ladder trading seems to be almost random dropping in of stakes and hoping it moves their way, and "scratching" when the marked PnL turns red.

I would think though most fall into the bracket of putting orders in hoping something will happen however

text: Yeah definitely. But I guess it's just a entirely different beast to auto so maybe trying to make it fit this paradigm isn't appropriate

text: there are a couple of Aus markets/tracks that I can regularly cream (month after month for 3-6 months so far) as far as ROI goes but am limited by scale (can make up to $20 a race)..all via ladders but on the whole predicting a trending move based on order flow thing-that remains a mystery to me. The online-verse is full of ladder 'experts' but (if that is all real) I am stuffed if I know how they do it so regularly year after year.

text: Do you not think that some of the stuff is pretty simple though? I mean you often see little wobbles when commentators comment on how a horse will perform. Or people with good horse body language reading ability or just laying something that looks very unhappy/sweating up etc. I am sure that the vast majority of people who use trading software are just kidding themselves though and making pretty much random entries. I know for a fact that I will never be able to do this though as I just find it too time consuming, not to mention incredibly dull.

text: Footie is one I just cannot understand unless you are trading big moves based on team news/injury etc. I don't understand how anything else football related inplay can be classed as "trading" because of the large discrete movements on a goal. The only steady move you get is the decay of the current state as the game progresses. What with that and Betfair's increasingly erratic and inconsistent game suspensions, "trading" football inplay seems just too risky for anything other than gambling - be it informed gambling or otherwise.

elements.text: Footie is one I just cannot understand unless you are trading big moves based on team news/injury etc. I don't understand how anything else football related inplay can be classed as "trading" because of the large discrete movements on a goal. The only steady move you get is the decay of the current state as the game progresses. What with that and Betfair's increasingly erratic and inconsistent game suspensions, "trading" football inplay seems just too risky for anything other than gambling - be it informed gambling or otherwise.

text: You can never guarantee your exit on an inplay trade because it is not that uncommon that more than one goal is scored within the same market suspension period so even planning on future price on event X occurring can lead to you getting stung badly.

elements.text: You can never guarantee your exit on an inplay trade because it is not that uncommon that more than one goal is scored within the same market suspension period so even planning on future price on event X occurring can lead to you getting stung badly.

text: I would guess that the percentage of profitable automated traders is higher than the percentage of manual traders, just because it is much much easier to be a compulsive gambler manually. But it doesn't really matter as it's hard to be profitable at all be it manual or automated. It's not necessarily a sensible comparison to make because the goals can be very very different. An automated trader could be looking to scrape pennies per event and cover thousands of events whereas a manual trader can only really look at one event at a time unless its a long term event spanning several days/weeks/months. At the end of the day whatever method used winners need to be taking money off losers.

text: As you said goals can be very very different. Personally I looked at trading as a challenge to become a better decision maker. That was the main goal. Regarding compulsive gamblers I would say that they do it only for the adrenaline shot. Imo the manual traders that have found the way to take consistent money from the market ever get near to that feeling.

text: You may have an opinion pre-event that is more scalable to execute in-play. Yes, the odds primarily move according to time decay but your opinion on how that delay manifests could differ from the market due to a different starting point and/or how the goals are expected to be distributed throughout the match

text: I hear what you are saying there and obviously the market seldom moves smoothly (one team dominates etc.) but it just scares because of the suspensions. Unless of course you are simply looking at taking value bets at various points inplay which is a very different thing to "trading". I don't know I am not looking down on it but I just think that the word "trading" gets overused in this area. If you are taking value it doesn't matter if the market suspends as you will just get your order cancelled. If you are looking to enter at event X then exit at event Y you just can't guarantee that you will be able to do it because of how the suspensions are handled. And this is exactly the kind of strategy I see called trading by many online.

elements.text: I hear what you are saying there and obviously the market seldom moves smoothly (one team dominates etc.) but it just scares because of the suspensions. If you are looking to enter at event X then exit at event Y you just can't guarantee that you will be able to do it because of how the suspensions are handled. And this is exactly the kind of strategy I see called trading by many online.

text:
Its probably fair to say that the biggest earners are all automated (some doing 6 figs a month), but not all automated traders are profitable either. There is at least one manual cricket trader that has earned >4m in lifetime profits that I seem to recall.
I would expect that that person has expended huge amounts of effort to get to that level. (By the way, I tried manual when first started and I was terrible at it :grinning:)!
